intro: Chamaecrista exigua var. exigua, commonly known as the narrowleaf crownflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its small, yellow, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert or arid environments. It has narrow, linear leaves and produces seed pods that split open to release its seeds. This species is valued for its ornamental appeal and its ability to thrive in challenging conditions.
